text:
The **economy of Fiji** is one of the most developed among the Pacific
islands. Nevertheless, Fiji is a developing country endowed with forest,
mineral and fish resources. The country has a large agriculture sector heavily
based on subsistence agriculture. Sugar exports and the tourism industry are
the main sources of foreign exchange. There are also light manufacturing and
mining sectors.

The country's petroleum production remains at zero despite previous hints at
reserves, and it relies entirely on imports to meet its refined petroleum
product needs.

As of 2025, Fiji's population was estimated to be approximately 949,992,
reflecting a 0.73% increase from the previous year. The country's tallest
building is the 30-story Grand Fijian Tower in Suva.
openai_summarised_points: • The economy of Fiji is considered one of the most developed among the Pacific islands, indicating a relatively higher level of economic activity and infrastructure compared to neighboring nations.

• Despite its development status, Fiji is classified as a developing country, with an economy endowed with natural resources such as forests, minerals, and fish, which contribute to its economic activities.

• The country's agriculture sector is large and predominantly based on subsistence farming, meaning a significant portion of agricultural output is consumed locally by farmers and their communities rather than for commercial export.
• Key sources of foreign exchange for Fiji are sugar exports and the tourism industry, which are the primary drivers of the country's foreign revenue.
• In addition to agriculture and tourism, Fiji has sectors of light manufacturing and mining, contributing to its economic diversification.

• Fiji's petroleum production remains at zero, despite previous indications or hints suggesting the presence of petroleum reserves, leading the country to rely entirely on imports to satisfy its refined petroleum product needs.
• As of the year 2025, Fiji's population was estimated to be approximately 949,992 individuals, reflecting a population growth rate of 0.73% compared to the previous year.
• The tallest building in Fiji is the 30-story Grand Fijian Tower located in Suva, serving as a notable landmark in the capital city.

text:
In September 2002, the government announced a 20-year development plan. Among
other things, it aimed to give indigenous Fijians a greater stake in the
economy. The plan envisages tax-relief to businesses owned or managed by
ethnic Fijians, along with greater protection for indigenous land and fishery
rights.

A major aim of the Fijian government is to achieve self-sufficiency in rice
production. Cattle farming, fishing, and forestry (especially pine trees) are
being encouraged to diversify the economy; the leading manufacturing
industries involve the processing of primary products. On 14 April 2005, the
Cabinet approved Prime Minister Laisenia Qarase's proposal to develop a
biofuels industry. Under the plan, ethanol is to be developed as a complement
to the sugar industry, with the hope of alleviating Fiji's dependence on
imported fossil fuel such as petrol.

On 15 August, Qarase said that the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP)
had granted assistance to Fiji to develop its biofuels project. Transformation
of the Fiji Sugar Corporation into an energy and sugar company would result in
a turnover of F$1 billion by 2025, he said, and would cut imports of crude
oil, generate export earnings, and provide a source of electricity. Energy
could be produced from copra, forest, and agricultural products, as well as
sugar. He touted the scheme as necessary for diversifying and strengthening
the sugar industry for its own survival, as well as for the national economy.
He said that the government of India had loaned F$86 million for upgrading of
Fiji's sugar mills, which would be completed in time for the 2007-2008
crushing season.

On 28 December 2005, John Teiwa of the Coconut Industry Development Authority
announced that a 20-year plan for the coconut industry would be launched in
2006. Financing from international investors, including the government of
India, would be sought to develop processing of virgin and extra virgin
coconut oil, with a view to venturing into foreign health markets. The
government expected an annual profit of F$120 million from the venture, Fiji
Village reported. Trials for the generation of fuel from coconut oil were also
in progress, Teiwa said.
openai_summarised_points: • In September 2002, the Fijian government announced a comprehensive 20-year development plan aimed at economic growth and social equity.
• The development plan specifically sought to increase indigenous Fijians' participation in the economy by providing tax relief to businesses owned or managed by ethnic Fijians.
• The plan included measures to enhance protection for indigenous land rights and fishery rights, emphasizing the importance of land and resource security for indigenous communities.
• A key objective of the government is to achieve self-sufficiency in rice production, reducing reliance on imports and promoting local agriculture.
• The government is actively encouraging diversification of the economy through cattle farming, fishing, and forestry, with particular emphasis on pine tree cultivation.
• The leading manufacturing industries in Fiji involve the processing of primary products, indicating a focus on value-added activities within resource-based sectors.
• On 14 April 2005, the Cabinet approved Prime Minister Laisenia Qarase's proposal to develop a biofuels industry as part of the national development strategy.
• The biofuels plan aims to develop ethanol as a supplement to the sugar industry, with the goal of reducing Fiji's dependence on imported fossil fuels such as petrol.
• On 15 August 2005, Qarase announced that the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) had granted assistance to Fiji for the development of its biofuels project.
• The transformation of the Fiji Sugar Corporation into an energy and sugar company was projected to generate a turnover of F$1 billion by 2025, contributing significantly to the national economy.
• The biofuels initiative is expected to help cut imports of crude oil, generate export earnings, and provide a sustainable source of electricity.
• Energy production from bioresources such as copra, forest products, agricultural products, and sugar is integral to the diversification strategy.
• Qarase emphasized that the biofuels scheme is necessary for diversifying and strengthening the sugar industry to ensure its survival and to bolster the overall economy.
• The government of India extended a loan of F$86 million for upgrading Fiji's sugar mills, with completion scheduled for the 2007-2008 crushing season.
• On 28 December 2005, John Teiwa of the Coconut Industry Development Authority announced the launch of a 20-year plan for the coconut industry in 2006.
• The coconut industry plan aims to develop processing facilities for virgin and extra virgin coconut oil, targeting entry into foreign health markets.
• International investors, including the government of India, are expected to provide financing for the coconut processing sector.
• The government projected an annual profit of F$120 million from the coconut industry venture.
• Trials are underway for generating fuel from coconut oil, indicating efforts to produce biofuels from coconut resources.

text:
Fiji has a large subsistence agriculture sector, which accounts for 18% of
gross domestic product, although it employed some 70% of the workforce as of
2001[_citation needed_]. Sugarcane is the main agricultural product grown in
Fiji. Other agricultural products grown in Fiji include coconuts, copra,
ginger, cassava, bananas, rice, sweet potatoes, taro, pickles, kava,
pineapples, and plantains. Livestock such as cattle, pigs, and goats are also
reared for meat. Fishing is important to the economy as well, with fish
products accounting for almost one-tenth of revenue from exports in the early
21st century. Lumber is another major industry, with timber being Fiji's
third-largest export commodity.

In 2018 Fiji produced:

* 1.3 million tons of sugarcane
* 72 thousand tons of cassava
* 49 thousand tons of taro
* 22 thousand tons of coconut
* 21 thousand tons of vegetable
* 10 thousand tons of ginger
* 8 thousand tons of sweet potato
* 7 thousand tons of rice
* 6 thousand tons of pineapple
* 5 thousand tons of plantain

In 2019 Fiji produced 41,892 tons of meat.
openai_summarised_points: • Fiji's agriculture sector includes a large subsistence component, which contributed approximately 18% to the gross domestic product (GDP) of Fiji.
• As of 2001, about 70% of Fiji's workforce was employed in agriculture, indicating the sector's significant role in employment despite its relatively modest contribution to GDP.
• The primary agricultural product in Fiji is sugarcane, which remains the dominant crop cultivated across the islands.
• Other notable agricultural products grown in Fiji include coconuts, copra (dried coconut kernel), ginger, cassava, bananas, rice, sweet potatoes, taro, pickles, kava, pineapples, and plantains.
• Livestock farming in Fiji involves cattle, pigs, and goats, which are reared primarily for meat production.
• Fishing holds considerable importance in Fiji’s economy, with fish products accounting for nearly 10% of export revenue in the early 21st century.
• The lumber industry is a major sector, with timber being Fiji’s third-largest export commodity, highlighting the significance of forestry exports.
• In 2018, Fiji produced approximately 1.3 million tons of sugarcane, underscoring its importance as a key agricultural crop.
• The same year, Fiji produced 72,000 tons of cassava, 49,000 tons of taro, and 22,000 tons of coconuts.
• Other 2018 agricultural outputs included 21,000 tons of vegetables, 10,000 tons of ginger, 8,000 tons of sweet potatoes, 7,000 tons of rice, 6,000 tons of pineapples, and 5,000 tons of plantains.
• In 2019, Fiji produced a total of 41,892 tons of meat, reflecting the scale of livestock and meat production within the country.

text:
Sugarcane processing makes up a significant portion of industrial activity.
Fiji also has successful garment manufacturing and mineral water bottling
industries. Other manufacturing activities include boat building, particularly
the construction of fishing boats and pleasure craft, cement making, brewing,
and paint manufacturing. Fiji is also a manufacturer and net exporter of wood
products such as pine chips, sawnwood and wood-based panels.
openai_summarised_points: • Sugarcane processing constitutes a major segment of Fiji's industrial activity, highlighting its importance within the manufacturing sector.
• Fiji has established successful industries in garment manufacturing and mineral water bottling, contributing significantly to its industrial output.

• Other notable manufacturing activities in Fiji include boat building, with a focus on the construction of fishing boats and pleasure craft, indicating a specialized maritime manufacturing capability.
• The manufacturing sector also encompasses cement production, brewing, and paint manufacturing, demonstrating diversification across various industrial sub-sectors.
• Fiji is a producer and net exporter of wood products, including pine chips, sawnwood, and wood-based panels, emphasizing its role in the forestry and timber industry.

text: Gold, silver, and copper are mined in Fiji.

Tourism has expanded rapidly since the early 1980s and is the leading economic
activity in the islands accounting for 24.4% of GDP in 2019. Excluding cruise
ship passengers, more than 960,000 people visited Fiji in 2019. An increase of
over 500,000 since 1999 when 409,000 tourists visited.[_citation needed_]

In 1999 a quarter of tourists came from Australia, with large contingents also
coming from New Zealand, Japan, the United States and United Kingdom. Over
62,000 of the tourists were American, a number that had steadily increased
since the start of regularly scheduled non-stop air service from Los Angeles.
Tourism earned more than $300 million in foreign exchange for Fiji in 1998, an
amount exceeding the revenue from its two largest goods exports (sugar and
garments).[_citation needed_]

The effects of the Asian financial crisis led to a sharp drop in the number of
Asian tourists visiting Fiji in 1997 and 1998, which contributed to a
substantial drop in gross domestic product. Positive growth returned in 1999,
however, aided by a 20% devaluation of the Fijian dollar. 2005 was a record
year for the tourism sector, with 9% growth according to Viliame Gavoka, Chief
Executive of the Fiji Visitors Bureau.[_citation needed_]
openai_summarised_points: • Tourism in Fiji has experienced rapid expansion since the early 1980s and has become the leading economic activity in the country.
• In 2019, tourism accounted for 24.4% of Fiji's Gross Domestic Product (GDP).
• Excluding cruise ship passengers, over 960,000 people visited Fiji in 2019.
• The number of tourists increased by more than 500,000 since 1999, when 409,000 tourists visited Fiji.
• In 1999, approximately 25% of tourists to Fiji originated from Australia.
• Significant contingents of tourists also came from New Zealand, Japan, the United States, and the United Kingdom.
• Over 62,000 American tourists visited Fiji in 1999, with this number steadily increasing following the start of regularly scheduled non-stop flights from Los Angeles.
• Tourism generated more than $300 million in foreign exchange for Fiji in 1998, surpassing the revenue from the country's two largest exports, sugar and garments.
• The Asian financial crisis caused a sharp decline in Asian tourists visiting Fiji in 1997 and 1998, which contributed to a substantial decrease in Fiji's gross domestic product.
• Positive tourism growth resumed in 1999, aided by a 20% devaluation of the Fijian dollar.
• The year 2005 marked a record year for Fiji's tourism sector, with a 9% growth rate reported by Viliame Gavoka, Chief Executive of the Fiji Visitors Bureau.

text:
Fiji has a high-tech industry with a number of software development companies
present in the country. In 2021, Fiji's high-tech exports were worth about
$1.95 million.
openai_summarised_points: • Fiji possesses a developing high-tech industry characterized by the presence of multiple software development companies operating within the country.
• In the year 2021, Fiji's high-tech exports were valued at approximately $1.95 million USD.

text:
| This section **does notcite any sources**. Please help improve this section
by adding citations to reliable sources. Unsourced material may be challenged
and removed. _( October 2024)__(Learn how and when to remove this message)_
---|---

Fiji runs a persistently large trade deficit. Imports in 1998 accounted for
US$721 million, and exports for US$510 million, resulting in a US$116 million
deficit. Tourism revenue yields services surplus, however, which keeps the
current account of its balance of payments roughly in balance ($13 million in
1998). Australia accounts for between 35% and 45% of Fiji's trade, with New
Zealand, the United States, the United Kingdom, and Japan varying year-by-year
between 5% and 15% each.

Foodstuffs, machinery, mineral fuels, beverages, tobacco, and manufactured
goods are the principal imports. The two largest exports are sugar and
garments, which each accounted for approximately one-quarter of export revenue
in 1998 (roughly $122 million each). The sugar industry suffered in 1997 due
to low world prices and rent disputes between farmers and landowners, and
again in 1998 from drought, but recovered in 1999.

The Fijian garment industry has developed rapidly since the introduction of
tax exemptions in 1988. The industry's output has increased nearly tenfold
since that time. Fish, lumber, molasses, coconut oil and ginger are also
important exports, although the last two are in decline. Forestry became
important as an export trade in the mid-1980s, when the pine plantations
planted in the 1950s and 1960s began to mature. They sell much fish.

Australia's Trade Commissioner Ross Bray revealed on 26 January 2006 that
Fiji's exports to Australia are achieving an annual growth rate of 5%. More
than 31,000 Australian companies were trading in the Pacific, half of them in
Fiji, Bray said. Fiji is progressing very rapidly.
openai_summarised_points: • Fiji consistently experiences a significant trade deficit, with imports in 1998 totaling US$721 million and exports totaling US$510 million, resulting in a US$116 million deficit.
• Despite the trade deficit, tourism revenue generates a services surplus, which helps maintain the overall current account balance of the balance of payments at approximately US$13 million in 1998.

• Australia is Fiji's primary trading partner, accounting for between 35% and 45% of Fiji's total trade, while New Zealand, the United States, the United Kingdom, and Japan each contribute between 5% and 15% of trade annually, with figures varying year by year.
• The principal imports into Fiji include foodstuffs, machinery, mineral fuels, beverages, tobacco, and manufactured goods.
• The two largest exports are sugar and garments, each representing roughly 25% of export revenue in 1998, with an approximate value of US$122 million each.
• The sugar industry faced challenges in 1997 due to low global prices and rent disputes between farmers and landowners, and again in 1998 due to drought; however, the industry recovered in 1999.
• The garment industry in Fiji has expanded rapidly since the introduction of tax exemptions in 1988, with output increasing nearly tenfold since that year.
• Additional important exports include fish, lumber, molasses, coconut oil, and ginger, although exports of ginger and coconut oil have been in decline.
• Forestry became a significant export sector in the mid-1980s, coinciding with the maturation of pine plantations established in the 1950s and 1960s.
• Fiji also exports substantial quantities of fish.
• On 26 January 2006, Australia's Trade Commissioner Ross Bray reported that Fiji's exports to Australia are growing at an annual rate of 5%.
• Over 31,000 Australian companies were engaged in trade within the Pacific region, with half of these companies operating in Fiji, indicating rapid economic progress for Fiji.

text:
The government's policy of awarding tax concessions to large multinational
companies investing in Fiji has not proved universally popular. The Asian
Development Bank (ADB) has criticized it, saying that the concessions have
been abused and have not generated long-term investment. An ADB report in 2005
accused foreign entrepreneurs of leaving as soon as their concessions expired,
and alleged that administration of the concessions encouraged corruption and
bribery.

The leader of the Fiji Labour Party Mahendra Chaudhry echoed the view of the
ADB on 31 December 2005, saying that foreign companies repatriated much of the
profit made in Fiji, rather than investing it locally, while taking advantage
of the infrastructure funded by Fijian taxpayers without paying any taxes
themselves. Such policy discriminated against local businesses, he
claimed.[_citation needed_]
openai_summarised_points: • The Fijian government has implemented a policy of granting tax concessions to large multinational companies investing in Fiji.
• This policy has not been universally popular and has faced criticism from various stakeholders.
• The Asian Development Bank (ADB) criticized the tax concession policy, stating that the concessions have been abused and have failed to generate long-term investment in Fiji.
• An ADB report published in 2005 accused foreign entrepreneurs of leaving Fiji immediately after their concessions expired.
• The report also alleged that the administration of these concessions fostered corruption and bribery.
• Mahendra Chaudhry, leader of the Fiji Labour Party, expressed similar concerns on 31 December 2005, criticizing the policy.
• Chaudhry claimed that foreign companies tend to repatriate most of the profits made in Fiji rather than reinvesting them locally.
• He argued that these companies benefit from Fiji’s infrastructure funded by taxpayers without paying taxes themselves.
• Chaudhry further claimed that the policy discriminates against local businesses.

text:
Fiji's economic difficulties have been compounded by the effects of four coups
since the 1980s.[_citation needed_]
openai_summarised_points: • Fiji's economic difficulties have been significantly exacerbated by the occurrence of four military coups since the 1980s.
• These political upheavals have contributed to economic instability, discouraging investment and disrupting economic activities.
• The coups have led to a decline in investor confidence, affecting both domestic and foreign investment flows into Fiji.
• The repeated political crises have hindered consistent economic policy implementation, further impeding economic growth and development.
• Specific details regarding the economic impact, such as quantitative data or the exact years of the coups, are not provided in this section.

text:
Since 1987, when the country was destabilized by two military coups, Fiji has
suffered a very high rate of emigration, particularly of skilled and
professional personnel. More than 70,000 people left the country in the
aftermath of the coups, majority of whom were Indo-Fijians. With the
continuing expiration of land leases and ongoing instability in the aftermath
of another coup in 2000, a further outflow of skilled workers has taken place.

A report in 2004 of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and
Development, published on 29 June 2005, found that 61% of Fiji's skilled
workers have either emigrated or gone abroad as guestworkers. Fiji's loss of
skilled workers was the world's fourth highest, behind Guyana, Jamaica, Haiti,
and Trinidad and Tobago. Fiji's Bureau of Statistics recorded 3595 workers as
having left the country between January and August 2004. Of these, 414 held
professional or technical jobs, 263 were in administrative or managerial
positions, and were clerks, supervisors, or related workers, and 118 were
sales workers.

Fiji's economy is increasingly reliant on remittances from citizens working
overseas. Personal remittances now run to more than F$200 million a year,
earning more than traditional sectors like sugar and garment manufacturing.
Recruitment of Fijians by foreign private military companies is a growing
source of revenue. By mid-2005, there were over 1,000 Fijians working in Iraq
and Kuwait as soldiers, security guards, drivers and labourers. In addition in
2006 there were more than 2,000 Fijian soldiers in the British Army, and in
2004 the British defence ministry even sent recruiting teams to Fiji to do
initial fitness and aptitude tests, cutting the costs of selection for poor
Fijian villagers who could not afford to fly to London to sign up.
openai_summarised_points: • Since 1987, following two military coups that destabilized Fiji, the country has experienced a very high rate of emigration, especially among skilled and professional personnel.
• Over 70,000 people left Fiji in the aftermath of these coups, with the majority being Indo-Fijians.
• The ongoing expiration of land leases and continued political instability after another coup in 2000 have contributed to further outflows of skilled workers.

• A 2004 report by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD), published on 29 June 2005, indicated that 61% of Fiji's skilled workers have either emigrated or gone abroad as guestworkers.
• Fiji's loss of skilled workers was the fourth highest globally, following Guyana, Jamaica, Haiti, and Trinidad and Tobago.

• Fiji's Bureau of Statistics recorded that between January and August 2004, 3,595 workers left the country; among these, 414 held professional or technical jobs, 263 were in administrative or managerial roles (including clerks and supervisors), and 118 were sales workers.

• The Fijian economy increasingly depends on remittances from citizens working overseas, which now exceed F$200 million annually, surpassing income from traditional sectors such as sugar and garment manufacturing.
• Recruitment of Fijians by foreign private military companies has become a growing source of revenue for Fiji.
• By mid-2005, over 1,000 Fijians were employed in Iraq and Kuwait as soldiers, security guards, drivers, and laborers.
• In 2006, more than 2,000 Fijian soldiers served in the British Army.

• In 2004, the British Defence Ministry sent recruiting teams to Fiji to conduct initial fitness and aptitude tests, reducing costs for poor Fijian villagers who could not afford to travel to London for recruitment.

text:
Low investment has been a long-term problem in Fiji, and property rights are
sometimes thought to be part of this problem because, by law, five sixths of
the land is owned communally by indigenous Fijians and may only be leased, not
purchased outright. However, the leasehold system is often misunderstood.

Leasehold tenure has not been a problem for the property sector. Houses all
over Fiji on communally owned land are on 99-year leases, which have proved
satisfactory as a basis for house ownership. Hotels also enjoy 99-year leases.
The prestigious Denarau development involving major hotels and resorts and
luxury properties is situated on communally owned land. It delivers
significant income to native owners and secure title to developers and their
customers.

In agricultural sector, there have been problems even though agricultural
leases are mandated at 30 years, following the extension by legislation (the
Agricultural Landlord and Tenant Act or ALTA) of all ten-year leases to thirty
years in 1977. The problem experienced in agriculture is the non-renewal
leases as landowners have been unhappy with the provisions in the ALTA for
indexing of rents to cope with inflation. That is an ongoing problem which
calls for urgent attention.
openai_summarised_points: • Low investment has been a persistent issue in Fiji's economy, with property rights often cited as a contributing factor.
• By law, five-sixths (approximately 83.33%) of land in Fiji is owned communally by indigenous Fijians, and such land can only be leased, not purchased outright.
• The leasehold system in Fiji is frequently misunderstood; it is not inherently problematic for the property sector.
• Houses built on communally owned land are typically on 99-year leases, which have proven to be a satisfactory basis for house ownership.
• The hotel industry also benefits from 99-year leases on communally owned land, facilitating tourism development.
• The Denarau development, a prominent area featuring major hotels, resorts, and luxury properties, is situated on communally owned land and generates significant income for native landowners.
• The Denarau project provides secure titles to developers and their customers, exemplifying successful leasehold arrangements.
• In agriculture, land lease issues have arisen despite the existence of a mandated 30-year lease period, following legislative extension.
• The Agricultural Landlord and Tenant Act (ALTA) of 1977 extended all ten-year agricultural leases to 30 years, aiming to improve land tenure stability.
• A key problem in agriculture involves the non-renewal of leases, as landowners have expressed dissatisfaction with ALTA provisions, particularly regarding rent indexing to inflation.
• The rent indexing provisions in ALTA, designed to adjust rents in response to inflation, have caused ongoing disputes and dissatisfaction among landowners.
• The non-renewal and rent-related issues in agricultural leases are considered urgent problems requiring immediate attention to improve land use and investment climate.

text:
Drought in 1998 further damaged the sugar industry, but its recovery in 1999
contributed to robust GDP growth. Further damage to the economy (estimated at
US$30 million) was wrought by a cyclone that hit the northern island of Vanua
Levu in January 2003. Apart from the economic devastation, there were food
shortages and outbreaks of disease due to the pollution of the water
supply.[_citation needed_]
openai_summarised_points: • In 1998, a drought significantly damaged Fiji's sugar industry, which is a vital sector of the country's economy.
• The sugar industry experienced a recovery in 1999, which contributed to strong overall GDP growth for Fiji during that period.
• In January 2003, a cyclone struck the northern island of Vanua Levu, causing an estimated US$30 million in economic damage.
• The cyclone's impact extended beyond economic losses, leading to food shortages across affected areas.
• The cyclone also caused outbreaks of disease, primarily due to pollution of the water supply resulting from the disaster.

text:
The aftermath of the political turmoil in 2000 resulted in a 10-percent
shrinkage in the economy, as investor confidence plummeted and tourist numbers
dropped more than 15% from 544,000 visitors in 1999 to under 434,000 by the
end of 2000. An estimated 7500 jobs were lost. There has been a gradual
recovery since 2001, when the 1997 constitution was restored and free
elections held.

The possibility of a return to a racially discriminatory constitution led to
fears that Fiji might forfeit its preferential arrangements with the European
Union for its sugar exports, and with Australia for its clothing industry, but
those fears have largely (but not entirely) subsided.
openai_summarised_points: • The political turmoil in Fiji in 2000 caused a 10-percent contraction of the country's economy.
• Investor confidence significantly declined following the political instability.
• Tourist arrivals decreased by more than 15%, dropping from 544,000 visitors in 1999 to under 434,000 by the end of 2000.
• Approximately 7,500 jobs were lost as a consequence of the economic downturn and decline in tourism.
• A gradual economic recovery began in 2001, coinciding with the restoration of the 1997 constitution and the holding of free elections.
• Concerns arose that a potential return to a racially discriminatory constitution could jeopardize Fiji’s preferential trade agreements.
• Specifically, there was fear that Fiji might lose its preferential arrangements with the European Union for sugar exports.
• Additionally, there were concerns about losing favorable trade terms with Australia for its clothing industry.
• These fears about the possible loss of trade preferences have largely subsided, though not entirely, since the political stabilization efforts.

text:
In June 2003, a survey revealed a disturbingly high percentage of squatters,
about a tenth of Fijian citizens. 82,350 individuals in 13,725 households were
estimated to live in 182 squatter settlements, with Suva and Nausori being the
worst-affected areas. The number of squatter settlements had increased 14%
since January 2001, and 73% since 1996. Urban migration, unemployment, the
expiry of land leases, and the breakdown of nuclear and extended families were
among the factors blamed for the trend. The report projected the population of
squatters to grow to 90,000 in the Suva-Nausori corridor by 2006, putting
increasing strain on supplies of water, electricity, sewage, and road
services. On 14 September, Prime Minister Qarase said that the squatter
problem had become so serious that the government was looking abroad for
funding.
openai_summarised_points: • In June 2003, a survey revealed that approximately 10% of Fijian citizens were squatters, indicating a significantly high prevalence of informal settlements in the country.
• The survey estimated that 82,350 individuals living in 13,725 households resided in 182 squatter settlements across Fiji.
• The most severely affected areas by squatter settlements were Suva and Nausori.
• The number of squatter settlements increased by 14% since January 2001 and by 73% since 1996, demonstrating rapid growth over recent years.
• Factors contributing to the rise in squatter settlements included urban migration, unemployment, the expiry of land leases, and the breakdown of nuclear and extended family structures.
• The report projected that the population of squatters in the Suva-Nausori corridor would grow to 90,000 by 2006, indicating ongoing and increasing urban informal settlement growth.
• The growth of squatter populations was expected to place increasing pressure on essential services such as water, electricity, sewage, and road infrastructure.

• On 14 September (year unspecified, but context suggests 2003), Prime Minister Qarase stated that the squatter problem had become so severe that the government was seeking funding from abroad to address the issue.

text:
On 11 September 2005, the publication of the United Nations Human Development
Index downgraded Fiji from 81st in 2004 to 92nd in 2005, behind Pacific
neighbours Tonga and Samoa. Incomes had improved, the report said, with gross
domestic product rising from F$5440 to F$5880, but other aspects of the
quality of life enjoyed by Fiji Islanders had deteriorated. Life expectancy
had declined from 72.9 in 2000 to 69.6 in 2004 and 67.8 in 2005, while
literacy remained unchanged at 93%.

Joji Kotobalavu, the chief executive of the Prime Minister's Office, branded
the report "a joke." His dismissal drew strong reaction from Opposition Leader
Mahendra Chaudhry, who said that whereas Kotobalavu was paid to be the Prime
Minister's spin doctor, the HDI report was put together by professionals who
had no hidden agendas, and should therefore be taken very seriously.

Since 2005, the Human Development Index of Fiji has steadily risen from a
reading of 0.687 to 0.743, just above the global median for all countries of
0.74. As of 2020 Fiji ranked 90th out of 183 countries on the Human
Development Index.
openai_summarised_points: • On 11 September 2005, the United Nations Human Development Index (HDI) downgraded Fiji from 81st place in 2004 to 92nd place in 2005, positioning it behind Pacific neighbors Tonga and Samoa.
• The report indicated that, despite improvements in income levels, other aspects of quality of life in Fiji had deteriorated.
• Fiji’s gross domestic product (GDP) increased from F$5440 to F$5880, reflecting economic growth.
• Life expectancy in Fiji declined from 72.9 years in 2000 to 69.6 years in 2004, and further to 67.8 years in 2005.
• Literacy rates in Fiji remained stable at 93% during this period.
• Joji Kotobalavu, the chief executive of the Prime Minister's Office, dismissed the HDI report as "a joke."
• Opposition Leader Mahendra Chaudhry criticized Kotobalavu’s dismissal, stating that the HDI report was compiled by professionals without hidden agendas and should be taken seriously.
• Since 2005, Fiji’s Human Development Index has steadily increased from 0.687 to 0.743.
• The current HDI value of 0.743 places Fiji just above the global median of 0.74.
• As of 2020, Fiji ranked 90th out of 183 countries on the Human Development Index.

text:
**Gross national product (GNP):** US$101.48 billion; US$1820 per capita (2000)

**Gross domestic product (GDP):** US$5.48 billion; $US 6,202.2 per capita
(2018)

purchasing power parity \- US$9.61 billion; US$11450 per capita (2020 estimate)

**GDP – real growth rate:** -6.6% (2008 est.)

**GDP – composition by sector:**
_agriculture:_ 8.9%
_industry:_ 13.5%

openai_summarised_points: • The Gross National Product (GNP) of Fiji was estimated at US$101.48 billion in the year 2000, with a per capita GNP of US$1820.
• The Gross Domestic Product (GDP) of Fiji was US$5.48 billion in 2018, with a per capita GDP of US$6,202.2.
• Based on a 2020 estimate using purchasing power parity (PPP), Fiji's GDP was US$9.61 billion, with a per capita PPP-adjusted GDP of US$11,450.
• Fiji experienced a real GDP growth rate of -6.6% in 2008, indicating an economic contraction during that year.
• The sectoral composition of Fiji's GDP in 2006 was approximately 8.9% from agriculture, 13.5% from industry, and 77.6% from services, highlighting a predominantly service-oriented economy.
• Approximately 25.5% of Fiji's population was living below the poverty line, reflecting significant income inequality and poverty levels.
• Data on household income or consumption distribution by percentage share is not available for the lowest 10% and highest 10%, as indicated by "NA%".

openai_summarised_points: • In 2020, Fiji's total electricity production was 1,000 GWh.
• The primary sources of electricity generation in Fiji in 2020 were fossil fuels, hydro, solar, and other sources, with no nuclear energy production.
• Fossil fuel-based electricity accounted for 420 GWh, representing 42% of the total electricity production in 2020.
• Hydropower contributed 500 GWh, making up 50% of the total electricity generation in 2020.
• Solar energy provided 20 GWh, constituting 2% of the total electricity produced in 2020.
• Other sources of electricity generation contributed 60 GWh, which is 6% of the total in 2020.
• Fiji produced no nuclear energy in 2020, with nuclear power contributing 0%.
• In 2019, Fiji's electricity consumption was slightly higher at 1,002 GWh.
• There were no electricity exports from Fiji in 2020, with export figures at 0 kWh.
• Similarly, Fiji did not import any electricity in 2020, with import figures at 0 kWh.

text:
The Fiji Rural Electrification Policy 1993 has been used by the Fiji
Department of Energy in the implementation of rural electrification projects
which includes diesel schemes for villages, micro hydro projects, house
wiring, biofuel projects, solar home systems and grid extension. Villages and
communities have been paying 10% of the total project costs and government
pays 90%. In 2010, government reduced the contribution from communities to 5%
and this has increased the number of applicants.
openai_summarised_points: • The Fiji Rural Electrification Policy was established in 1993 to guide rural electrification initiatives in Fiji.
• The Fiji Department of Energy utilizes this policy to implement various rural electrification projects.
• These projects include diesel schemes for villages, micro hydro projects, house wiring programs, biofuel projects, solar home systems, and grid extension efforts.
• Funding structure for these projects involves villages and communities contributing 10% of the total project costs, with the government covering the remaining 90%.
• In 2010, the Fijian government reduced the community contribution requirement from 10% to 5%.
• The reduction in community contribution from 10% to 5% in 2010 led to an increase in the number of applicants for rural electrification projects.

text:
**Agriculture – products:** sugar cane, coconuts, cassava (tapioca), rice,
sweet potatoes, bananas, ginger, taro, kava; livestock: cattle, pigs, shrimp,
pickles, goats; fish. Island economies are at a disadvantage for harnessing
export opportunities due to the costs of transport.[_citation needed_] The
Fijian island of Cicia has set the goal of achieving 100% organic farming
which can bring with it economic and environmental benefits.

US$921 million (1998)

**Imports – commodities:** machinery and transport equipment, petroleum
products, food, chemicals.

One in every seven dollars of Fiji's national income is spent on oil according
to the World Bank.

**Imports – partners:** Australia 35%, Japan 4.8%, Singapore 19.2%, New
Zealand 17.1% (2003).
